statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the plane passing through the point $(-1,-1,2)$ and perpendicular to each of the planes: $2x+3y-3z=2$ and $5x-4y+z=6$. %

step.context: %text If A, B and C are the direction ratios of a plane that passes through $(-1,-1,2)$, what is the equation of the plane? %
step.reason: %text The equation of a plane having direction ratios A, B and C, which contains point $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$, is given by, % \qquad A(x-x_1)+B(y-y_1)+C(z-z_1)=0 \\ %text Therefore for the given plane which contains $(-1,-1,2)$, the equation is, % \qquad A(x+1)+B(y+1)+C(z-2)=0

step.context: %text If $A(x+1)+B(y+1)+C(z-2)=0$ is perpendicular to $2x+3y-3z=2$ and $5x-4y+z=6$, which of the following is true? %
step.reason: %text If two planes with direction ratios $a_1$, $b_1$, $c_1$ and $a_2$, $b_2$, $c_2$ respectively, are $\perp$ their normals are also perpendicular. Therefore their direction ratios represent vectors whose dot-product is zero. Hence, % \qquad a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2=0 \\ %text for perpendicular planes. %

step.context: %text If $A(x+1)+B(y+1)+C(z-2)=0$ and % \qquad \begin{align} & 2A+3B-3C=0 \\ & 5A-4B+C=0 \end{align} \\ %text what is the final equation of the plane? %
step.reason:
\qquad\begin{align} & 2A+3B-3C=0 \\ & 5A-4B+C=0 \end{align} \\ %text Using the above equations and expressing A and B in terms of C we get, % \qquad {\bf A:B:C=9:17:23} \\ %text
Substituting A. B and C as $9k$, $17k$ and $23k$ in $A(x+1)+B(y+1)+C(z-2)=0$, % \begin{align} & 9k(x+1)+17k(y+1)+23k(z-2)=0 \\ \implies & 9x+9+17y+17+23z-46=0 \\ \implies & {\bf 9x+17y+23z=20} \end{align}
